title: How to Make Wedding Signs

steps.headline: Purchase plywood boards from a home improvement store.
steps.description: Plywood boards are cheap, so they are commonly used for homemade signs. Preparing the wood isn't necessary, but you can refine it by sanding the wood with a 60 to 80 medium-grit sandpaper followed by a 100 to 180 fine-grit sandpaper. Also try staining it to give it a unique color fitting a formal celebration. You can also cut the wood with a handsaw or circular saw if you want your sign to be a specific size. Staining is good for darkening and preserving wood. Use a paintbrush to coat the wood in a commercial stainer. EXPERT TIP																															Megan Papageorge																Certified Wedding Planner								Megan Papageorge is a Certified Wedding Planner and Owner of Sweet Peach Planning, a wedding planning and management company based in Long Beach, California. She has completed over 200 weddings in settings such as gondolas, church halls, the side of cliffs, and vintage warehouses. Megan also co-hosts Peach & Honey, a wedding planning podcast. She is certified to plan and run weddings by the Bridal Society Educational Course. Her work has been featured in A Practical Wedding, Junebug Weddings, Ceremony Magazine, and The Bridal Society. Megan Papageorge			Certified Wedding Planner				Expert Trick: For a cute, unique alternative to making a sign, try painting calligraphy on balloons! For instance, you might make one balloon that says "Mr." and one that say "Mrs.," or you might have balloons with arrows pointing the direction guests should go.

steps.headline: Create your design on a word processor.
steps.description: Choose a classy font from the drop-down menu and type out the words you want to appear on your sign. Use the size settings to make the words as large as you need them to be on your sign. For more space, try flipping the page to landscape mode using the settings tab in the upper-right corner of the screen. Make the font big, since people will be reading your sign from afar.

steps.headline: Print out the design components on paper.
steps.description: For smaller signs, you may be able to print the whole design in 1 document. If you are short on space, break the design into smaller pieces. Print it 1 word at a time so the design looks as big and impressive as it needs to be for a wedding. To print 1 word at a time, move the other words to separate word processor files. Then print each file. If you print words together in the same document, leave a few spaces between them. You may cut the paper to separate the words, making them easier to arrange.

steps.headline: Tape the design on top of the sign.
steps.description: Lay your sign down on a flat surface, then arrange your design pages on top of it. Make sure all the words are the right size before you start drawing. Once you are ready, hold the paper down with masking tape. You can use graphite transfer paper from a craft store to make the design transfer show up better. Place the matte side face-down beneath the design.

steps.headline: Outline your design with a sharp pencil.
steps.description: The pencil should be sharp enough that it pushes the lead into the wood, so that you can see the words once you remove the paper. Make sure to trace around all of the letters in your design. Hold the pencil down with firm pressure but don't let it tear through the paper.

steps.headline: Remove the papers from the sign.
steps.description: Peel back the tape to get a glimpse of your design in action. You should be able to see the outline without much trouble. Erase, adjust, and retrace your design as needed until it looks perfect.

steps.headline: Color the design with markers.
steps.description: Chalk ink markers create bright, white lines that match well with the other art on display, like cake or the bride's dress. Use it to outline the letters a second time, then color them in. For more color, try paint or paint markers. All of these supplies are available at most art supply stores.

steps.headline: Draw additional decorations on your sign.
steps.description: Take a step back and admire your work. You can customize your sign further if it seems a little empty. Consider printing out an image using the same process and tracing it onto the sign. Alternatively, paint on flowers or other decorations by hand to add your own personal flare.

steps.headline: Spray paint the sign with a background color.
steps.description: Plywood is the main choice for sign material, although other surfaces work too. Pick up a can of spray paint in a color that is pleasant as a background, such as black. Working in a well-ventilated area, spray the paint across the wood in short, even strokes.

steps.headline: Wait up to 5 minutes for the paint to dry.
steps.description: Follow the manufacturer's instructions on how long to wait until the paint dries. The paint doesn't need to be fully dry, since you'll be applying multiple coats.

steps.headline: Paint the sign again up to 5 times.
steps.description: Spray painting typically means a few coats of paint. Go over the sign once, then wait at least 5 minutes for the paint to dry a little. Repeat until the sign's coloring looks smooth and even.

steps.headline: Wait a day for the paint to dry fully.
steps.description: Leave the sign in an area where it won't be disturbed by you, a pet, or the elements.

steps.headline: Place adhesive stencils over the board.
steps.description: Before removing the adhesive backing and pressing the stencils onto your sign, take a step back and confirm it look the way you want it to. Ask a friend to confirm they can read everything from afar. Purchase adhesive stencils at your local craft supply store. You may be able to work with non-adhesive stencils. Try to hold these down with masking tape. If you can’t find a stencil you want, try making a design on a computer or by cutting stencil paper with a craft knife.

steps.headline: Paint over the stencils with acrylic paint.
steps.description: Make sure you're painting directly over the stencil, and avoid getting paint under the stencil, which could ruin the words. Brush paint until the stencil is fully covered. Spray paint works well for larger stencils or if you use painter’s tape to protect the space around the stencils. Instead of using stencils and acrylics, you can use stickers and spray paint. Peel the stickers and place them on the sign, then spray paint over them. It's a fast way to make a simple sign.

steps.headline: Remove the stencils immediately after painting them.
steps.description: As soon as you are done paining, peel off the stencils. If you can't to keep them, clean them by washing them in the sink with warm water and whatever dish soap you have on hand. The stencils are reusable, so set them aside in case you need them again. If you don’t plan on using the stencils again, you can always throw them away.

steps.headline: Finish the signs with stickers and additional decorations.
steps.description: Now comes the best part. Once you have the basic design in place, come up with ways to personalize the sign for the big event. You can glue on stickers, ribbons, photos, and other decorations. Try holding them in place with decoupage glue, wood glue, or clear tape. You can always paint on special pictures or messages. Get creative and make this sign your own.

steps.headline: Sand the plywood down with a 100 to 180 fine-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Pick out a solid piece of plywood from a home improvement store or improvise with scrap wood. Smooth it out before attempting to paint it. Rub the entire surface gently with a piece of sandpaper rated between 100 and 180-grit. To wear down tough spots on the wood, start with a 60 to 80 medium grit sandpaper. Follow up with the fine-grit sandpaper. Signs are most often made out of wood, but you can attempt to make yours out of glass or metal. Follow the same steps but skip the sanding.

steps.headline: Paint the sign with a roller and chalkboard paint.
steps.description: Pour the paint into a tray and load it onto the roller. Then go over the sign once to coat it. Cover the entire sign, applying the paint as evenly as possible.

steps.headline: Wait about 2 hours for the paint to dry.
steps.description: Read the manufacturer’s instructions on the label to find out how long to wait. The paint should become dry to the touch within 2 hours. Avoid waiting longer, or else the paint will settle completely.

steps.headline: Sand the paint after it dries.
steps.description: Use the fine-grit sandpaper again. Go over the entire sign to smooth out the paint layer. If you find any difficult spots, use the medium-grit sandpaper first.

steps.headline: Repeat painting and sanding up to 5 times.
steps.description: Roll on another layer of paint, then let it dry for another 2 hours. The trick is to get the paint to look thick and even. You shouldn't be able to see any wood once you're finished.

steps.headline: Dry the sign for 72 hours.
steps.description: Set the chalkboard sign aside for a few days. Make sure it's in a location where it won't be disturbed by an accidental passerby, pet, or the elements. If your sign is ruined while it's drying, you can simply paint and sand it again!

steps.headline: Rub chalk over the sign to protect your sign.
steps.description: In order to protect the chalkboard once you've painted it, rub a piece of chalk until you've completely covered the sign's surface. Then, simply remove it with a clean rag, and your sign is ready! You can repeat this every time you erase your chalkboard for a longer lasting sign.

steps.headline: Draw your design on the board with chalk.
steps.description: Use the chalk stick to create a quick but temporary design. Chalk ink pencils and markers are other options available to you. These aren’t permanent either, but they come in a variety of colors you can use to make brighter signs.

steps.headline: Cut the wood to size.
steps.description: First, obtain a piece of plywood, then cut it to the width you want your finished sign to be. The employees at your local home improvement store can help you with this. They can also cut the wood to length if you know how long you want the finished sign to be. You can also cut the sign yourself using a hand saw, circular saw, or miter saw. Be sure to take safety precautions, such as by wearing gloves and polycarbonate goggles.

steps.headline: Trace and cut lines on the end of the wood to create the arrow shape.
steps.description: Draw diagonal lines from about 5 in (13 cm) down the longer ends to the center point with a pencil. Once you've drawn your arrow lines, erase and adjust as necessary before cutting. You can cut your arrow lines at your local home improvement store or at home. The measurements vary depending on your sign. Adjust your lines as needed to make them even. If you don’t want to cut the wood, you can also simply draw an arrow on the sign!

steps.headline: Sand the wood with 120 to 180 fine-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: All you need is a single piece of fine-grit sandpaper. Lightly rub down the entire board. It should feel smooth to the touch. If you notice any rough spots, go over them with a 60 to 80 medium-grit sandpaper, followed by the fine-grit sandpaper.

steps.headline: Color the wood using a wood stainer.
steps.description: Put on rubber gloves before handling a commercial wood stainer. Stir the stainer with a brush, then paint it onto the wood. Go over the entire surface in short, even strokes. Stainer gives wood a dark, refined color that goes well with the lighter colors prevalent at weddings.

steps.headline: Let the stainer dry for up to 2 days.
steps.description: Read the manufacturer’s instructions to find out how long you need to wait. Make sure you set the sign aside so it isn't disturbed.

steps.headline: Apply another coat of stainer if you want a darker sign.
steps.description: Paint on the stainer the same way you did before. You will need to wait another 2 days for the sign to dry. Set it aside in a safe spot, then use your down time to assemble your design.

steps.headline: Print your design on a computer if you want a stenciled look.
steps.description: An easy way to create a pointed sign is with the printed transfer method. In this, you create your design in a word document on the computer. Directional signs usually use just 1 word, so keep your sign simple. Make the word the same size as your sign.

steps.headline: Transfer your stencil onto the sign using a sharp pencil or draw your design directly on the sign.
steps.description: Tape the design paper on top of your sign. All you need is a sharp pencil to finish transferring the design. Trace around all the letters. Press firmly, but don’t let the pencil break through the paper.

steps.headline: Color in the letters using a chalk marker.
steps.description: White chalk markers are contrast well against stained wood, but you can try other colors. Remove the papers from the sign, then use the marker to trace around the letters. Then color them in to finish the design. Your sign should look pretty vibrant now. You usually don’t need to add any extra decorations here. Keep it simple so everyone realizes the sign is guiding them.

Repeat painting and sanding up to 5 times.

Set the chalkboard sign aside for a few days.

Rub chalk over the sign to protect your sign.

Creating a Pointed Sign Cut the wood to size.
First, obtain a piece of plywood, then cut it to the width you want your finished sign to be.
The employees at your local home improvement store can help you with this.
They can also cut the wood to length if you know how long you want the finished sign to be.
You can also cut the sign yourself using a hand saw, circular saw, or miter saw.
Be sure to take safety precautions, such as by wearing gloves and polycarbonate goggles.
Trace and cut lines on the end of the wood to create the arrow shape.
Draw diagonal lines from about 5 in (13 cm) down the longer ends to the center point with a pencil.
Once you've drawn your arrow lines, erase and adjust as necessary before cutting.
You can cut your arrow lines at your local home improvement store or at home.
The measurements vary depending on your sign.
Adjust your lines as needed to make them even.
If you don’t want to cut the wood, you can also simply draw an arrow on the sign!
Sand the wood with 120 to 180 fine-grit sandpaper.
All you need is a single piece of fine-grit sandpaper.
Lightly rub down the entire board.
It should feel smooth to the touch.
If you notice any rough spots, go over them with a 60 to 80 medium-grit sandpaper, followed by the fine-grit sandpaper.
Color the wood using a wood stainer.
Put on rubber gloves before handling a commercial wood stainer.
Stir the stainer with a brush, then paint it onto the wood.
Go over the entire surface in short, even strokes.
Stainer gives wood a dark, refined color that goes well with the lighter colors prevalent at weddings.
Let the stainer dry for up to 2 days.
Read the manufacturer’s instructions to find out how long you need to wait.
Make sure you set the sign aside so it isn't disturbed.
Apply another coat of stainer if you want a darker sign.
Paint on the stainer the same way you did before.

Transfer your stencil onto the sign using a sharp pencil or draw your design directly on the sign.
Tape the design paper on top of your sign.

Color in the letters using a chalk marker.
